0.00.text:
Translator: Emily Biegas
Reviewer: Maricene Crus

16.80.text:
but not everybody gets
the good life, right?

22.02.text:
if right now, today, how much 
more successful would you be

25.67.text: if you just started a company

27.75.text:
50/50 with Bill Gates 
as your business partner

30.75.text:
and he was using every trick of the trade
that he used to build Microsoft

34.71.text:
into one of the biggest 
companies in the world?

37.07.text:
Imagine how much money you'd have
in your bank account today -

40.70.text: how much more money, I should say -

42.41.text:
if Warren Buffet was teaching you 
how to invest in the stock market,

47.12.text:
showing you what he used 
to build Berkshire Hathaway

52.80.text: Imagine how much happier you'd be today

56.15.text: if the Dali Lama was your personal guide,

58.63.text:
showing you how to find 
fulfillment in life,

61.00.text:
in the little things
that most people overlook.

64.00.text: Imagine how healthy you'd be today

69.99.text: you went down to your gym,

71.42.text:
and Arnold Schwarzenegger 
was waiting there,

75.53.text: showing you how he built his body

77.58.text: into the most fit body maybe ever, right?

80.48.text:
Imagine the change you'd be 
making in the world,

83.92.text: the injustice you'd be solving today,

86.66.text:
if Mother Theresa and you
were running a charity together

90.80.text: and she was showing you what she learned

93.06.text:
on the streets of Calcutta,
helping the poor, the sick, and the dying.

98.87.text:
Mentors have the power
to do this in your life.

102.50.text:
I think everybody here recognizes
the importance of a role model.

107.47.text: But in the next few minutes,

108.82.text:
I'm going to show you how
mentors are more powerful

114.25.text:
in their ability
to transform your life.

117.42.text:
It's interesting that 
I'm here in Luxembourg,

119.67.text:
because my grandmother 
was born not too far from here,

124.33.text: She's 96 years old, by the way,

126.08.text: and she said, "Tai, tell them hello."

131.21.text:
She said, "There was a role model,
a mentor that I had

134.03.text: when I was a little girl."

135.33.text: She was born in 1918 in Berlin,

137.41.text:
and she said, "We had a renter
in our house."

141.48.text:
Edith Knox, who was
a famous piano player

145.28.text:
She said, "Tai, this woman 
made such an impression on me."

148.43.text: She rented a room for a summer,

150.52.text:
and she said, 
"Edith Knox wore pants."

153.36.text:
My grandma said, "I'd never seen
a woman wear pants."

155.90.text:
Apparently, in Germany in the '20s,
no women wore pants.

158.59.text:
And not just regular pants.
She had an orange jumpsuit on.

162.15.text:
And then she'd play the piano,
and Edith Knox, every hour,

164.86.text: would stand on her head for exercise.

167.14.text: My grandma was like 7 and she said,

168.86.text:
"Tai, I thought if that's how women
are in California,

172.86.text: one day I'm going to move to California."

175.64.text:
And sure enough,
she ended up in California.

177.69.text:
That's part of the story of how 
my family ended up in California.

181.11.text: I'm from California. I flew here.

183.56.text:
It took me 20 hours to get here, 
and I'm from Hollywood, specifically.

192.41.text:
Or for most people,
it's the land of broken dreams.

195.65.text:
Every year, 100,000 people
move in and out of Hollywood.

199.04.text:
Some come to be movie stars,
actors, singers, writers, comedians.

208.41.text: So I live up in the Hills,

210.11.text:
and I'm surrounded 
by all these celebrities.

212.34.text:
I have one on my left,
one on my right.

214.22.text:
I often think, "Why did 
these celebrities make it?

217.70.text:
What did they do differently
that allowed them to make it?"

221.50.text:
Because in Hollywood,
everybody wants something,

225.25.text:
but not everybody gets
what they want.

229.43.text:
So I want to talk a little bit
about that today.

233.99.text:
I think we all realize the sands of time
quickly can slip by in your life.

238.86.text:
And you don't want to be old
when you finally get the good life,

246.56.text: "We're too soon old, too late smart."

249.86.text:
Steve Jobs said, "I didn't want to be
be the richest man in the graveyard."

256.37.text: I remember back, I was younger

259.14.text:
and Alan Nation, one of my mentors,
he had told me,

262.17.text:
"Tai, what did you want to be
when you were 16?

266.66.text: That's the truest version of yourself.

268.62.text:
What did you want to be
when you were 16?"

270.66.text:
And I remember at 16,
I wanted to find the good life.

274.83.text:
Aristotle talks about eudaimonia,
his definition of the good life.

278.83.text:
Health, wealth, happiness, love.
All those things.

283.27.text:
I remember going, "It's too hard. 
How am I ever going to figure this out?

286.76.text:
There's so many hard questions. 
I'm 16.

288.71.text:
I got to figure out what college to go to,
what religion I'm going to follow,

292.33.text:
who I'm going to marry,
what politics, where to live,

294.98.text: what career and path to pursue."

296.97.text:
And I had this idea.
I was like, "I know the perfect idea."

301.60.text:
I thought this was so genius,
it turned out to not be so smart -

304.65.text:
But I'd find one person
who had all the answers.

307.97.text:
The smartest person I could think of
was my grandfather.

310.63.text:
I wrote this letter: "Will you tell me 
how to design my life?"

316.11.text:
The "D" is about Design,
the designed life.

318.89.text:
So I said, "Will you help me
design my life?"

322.40.text:
Four days later I got this letter 
back from my grandpa

325.82.text:
I read it and it said, 
"Sorry, Tai, I can't help you.

332.68.text:
You will never find all the answers
from just one person.

335.85.text:
If you're lucky, a handful of people
along the way will point the way."

339.24.text:
And I was like, "Ugh!"
So much for my shortcut.

342.47.text: But seven days later, a package came.

349.88.text: and he had sent me some old dusty ones.

354.66.text:
"The Story of Civilization," 
by Will and Ariel Durant.

357.29.text:
I was like, "1,000 pages? 
This is too much."

360.09.text:
But I see now, he was giving me 
a hint, I didn't understand it.

363.57.text:
There's this myth that you 
have to go inward to find truth.

367.55.text:
But the truth he was saying 
is you have to go outward.

370.15.text:
If you can download the consciousness,
the mindset of people

376.08.text:
the smartest, the wisest, 
the most intelligent,

379.99.text: then you will get what you want.

382.37.text:
And so I went on, and I started 
writing down note cards.

385.63.text:
I called them mental shortcuts.
And I was reading these books.

388.57.text:
And then I started traveling.
I went to 51 countries.

391.08.text:
I'd read a book and say,
"Let me go visit this person in person."

394.34.text: So I went to New Zealand and Australia,

396.82.text:
South America, Argentina, Ireland,
all over the world.

400.60.text:
I was focused on those 4 things:
health, wealth, love, and happiness.

403.85.text:
I decided to focus 
on health and happiness.

405.90.text: I lived for two years with Joel Salatin

408.15.text:
on his famous sustainable 
agricultural organic farm.

410.63.text: Then I spent 2 1/2 years with the Amish.

413.18.text:
No electricity, trying to see what 
was life when we lived in community.

417.66.text:
I made one mistake.
I forgot about money.

420.31.text:
That's one of the things, 
so eventually, I ran out of money.

423.23.text:
I had to do the thing nobody wants to do,
call my mom and be like,

426.35.text:
"Mom, I know I'm an adult,
but I don't have any money.

428.93.text:
Do you mind if I come stay at home
until I get back on my feet?"

431.94.text:
She had a mobile home 
in Clayton, North Carolina.

435.81.text:
"Sorry, Tai, I don't have a room for you,
but you can sleep on this couch."

440.19.text:
So I remember laying there at night, 
like: "Did I mess up?

443.95.text: Did I miss out on the good life?

445.81.text: Here I am, I have no college degree.

449.13.text:
My skills? 
I could milk a cow with the Amish."

451.50.text: That wasn't a very marketable skill.

454.43.text:
I remember I had like $47 
in my bank account.

457.86.text:
I had a car, 
but it had holes in the floor.

463.05.text:
and if you accidentally 
would put your foot down,

465.41.text:
it would chop your foot off.
So I didn't want to drive it anywhere,

469.33.text: or pick anybody up in that car.

471.43.text:
I remembered back to what 
my grandpa said, "Look outwards."

474.74.text:
So I started asking around:
"Will somebody help me?"

477.17.text:
My uncle said: "You need somebody 
who'll show you how to make money."

480.50.text:
So I was like, "Great idea.
I'm going to go find somebody."

483.31.text: But I didn't have any gas money.

485.15.text:
I was stuck there
at my mom's house. I had $40.

488.15.text:
I walked to the kitchen.
That's what I could afford to do.

490.87.text:
I found the yellow pages 
and opened them up.

493.27.text:
I looked in the finance section
and I found this guy.

495.77.text: I said, "I'm going to visit this guy."

497.68.text: So I got a suit out of the closet.

499.33.text:
It wasn't mine, it was too big.
It looked weird on me.

501.85.text:
I don't know what I looked like
when I showed up at that guy's house.

505.11.text: I got somebody to drive me in,

506.58.text:
I showed up and Kathy, his secretary, 
opened the door and I walked back,

510.04.text:
and Mike Steinback, from the phone book,
I walked up to him and I said,

513.37.text:
"Mike, you don't know me.
If you show me what you know,

516.75.text:
- you must know a lot about money, 
if you can afford a full-page ad

521.17.text:
if you show me what you know
I'll work for you for free."

523.85.text:
I'll never forget.
He was sitting in this chair.

526.12.text:
He had a big mustache.
He looked kind of like Tom Selick.

528.80.text:
He was sitting there,
and he just rolled his chair towards me.

531.71.text:
And he said, "You know, Tai? I've been 
looking for someone like you for 20 years.

535.58.text:
Show up in the morning,
I'll show you what I know."

538.16.text: And sure enough, he did show me.

540.01.text: And he began to mentor me on business.

542.31.text:
And now I'm an entrepreneur.
I'm an investor.

545.14.text:
But I've continued on that path,
traveling, finding mentors, reading.

549.12.text: I read a book a day.

551.66.text: I have a little book club, I write.

553.35.text:
And what I've found in my research
is that I wasn't the abnormal path.

557.88.text:
Mentors - your ability to copy -
is the biggest predictor

562.69.text: of the success that you will have in life.

564.70.text:
As Picasso said, "Good artists copy, 
but great artists steal."

571.60.text: And I looked around, and it's interesting.

573.83.text:
Did you know Albert Einstein
had a mentor?

576.17.text:
Every Thursday, he would have 
lunch with a mentor growing up.

579.08.text: Jay-Z, the rapper, he had a mentor.

581.09.text: Oprah Winfrey said she had two mentors.

595.58.text:
There's something here
that most of us

599.73.text:
So I want to share with you
some things that I've found,

602.42.text:
some specifics that you 
can do with mentors.

605.09.text:
The first rule, 
I call it the Mentor Rules.

611.46.text:
You should divide up your life
and spend 33% of your time

616.78.text: You can mentor and help them.

618.34.text:
And they'll help you back by making 
you feel good about yourself.

621.46.text:
It's good to know somebody's 
doing worse than you. That's that 30%.

625.15.text:
Then you have 33% of people
that are on your level.

627.95.text: These become your friends, your peers.

630.29.text:
But that last 33% is what 
most people forget about.

633.15.text:
Those are people 10, 
20 years ahead of you.

635.84.text:
They'll make you feel 
a little bit uncomfortable,

638.19.text: but that's what you want, and remember

640.63.text:
you don't want to make the mistake
most people make with mentors,

643.78.text:
finding somebody just
a little bit better than them.

646.22.text:
You don't want to be the blind
leading the blind.

648.53.text:
So I call it the 10x rule; find somebody 
ten times further ahead than you.

652.12.text:
If you want to learn how to grow
a $1 million company,

654.74.text:
you have to find somebody
who has a $10 million company.

657.73.text: Don't be afraid to go to the top.

662.09.text:
And you can get people 
like Warren Buffet, Bill Gates.

666.06.text:
My friend Frank heard a talk.
He's a director in Hollywood.

668.76.text:
He's like, "Tai, you won't believe this.
I heard your talk and emailed some people.

672.68.text: And Elon Musk, the founder of Paypal,

674.77.text:
the only man to own three companies worth 
$1 billion wrote me back and we had lunch.

678.89.text:
You'd be surprised,
because people remember.

680.97.text:
They remember their struggle,
and they'll reach out and help you, too.

684.30.text: Remember, everybody wants the good life,

687.40.text:
but not everybody's willing
to follow these rules.

694.80.text:
One of my favorite stories in business,
Sam Walton.

697.37.text: He becomes the richest man in America.

699.85.text: He starts Walmart, this big empire.

702.15.text: And he takes a trip to São Paulo, Brazil.

704.48.text:
And when he's there, his host family
gets a call from the police department.

709.40.text:
They're like, "Come bail out
Sam Walton. He's in jail."

711.99.text:
By this time, he's an older guy.
Billionaire.

715.80.text:
If you've ever seen the inside
of a Brazilian jail cell,

718.68.text:
it's not a good place 
for a 60-year-old billionaire.

721.24.text:
And they asked the police, "Are you crazy?
Are you arresting him?"

724.36.text: They're like, "We didn't know who he was,

726.44.text:
and we found him crawling around
the floors of stores."

729.18.text: They asked him what he was doing,

732.33.text:
and he's like, "I was just measuring how
wide the aisles were with a tape measurer.

736.61.text:
I was trying to figure out 
if these Brazilians knew

741.40.text:
Already a billionaire.
You'd think he'd be cocky.

744.13.text: You see, everybody wants the good life,

747.14.text:
but not everybody's willing 
to be humble like Sam Walton was.

756.58.text:
They only show us the success at the end,
but Bill Gates started at 12.

760.29.text:
It wasn't until 31 years old
that he was a billionaire.

763.18.text:
He said from age 20 to 30,
he never took a day off. Not even one.

768.34.text:
and in your search for mentors
you must persevere, as well.

771.12.text: I've been lucky to become friends

772.70.text:
with one of the top real estate 
investors in the world.

775.33.text: I said, "How did you get started?"

776.99.text:
He said, "Back when he was 19,
I decided I wanted to do real estate.

780.22.text:
I lived in a little town, but there was 
one developer who was pretty good.

783.78.text:
So I went down to the developer's office.
I met the secretary.

786.68.text: I said, 'I'd like to meet this developer.'

788.76.text:
She said, 'Sorry. He's a busy man.
He doesn't have time to meet you.'"

792.05.text:
He went back the next day.
She turned him away.

795.57.text:
He said on the 17th time, 
the lady felt bad for him and she said,

798.71.text:
"Here's what you do. Hide
behind the plant by the elevator.

801.75.text:
When he comes out of his office
at the end of the day,

805.76.text:
And he won't have a choice.
The doors will close.

808.06.text:
And you've got four floors
to convince this guy

812.23.text:
I don't know what my friend said,
but he said enough

814.67.text:
that when they got to the bottom
of the elevator,

817.17.text:
that developer said, 
"Meet me at the airport in the morning.

820.11.text:
We'll go down to my private jet.
You can come down with me to Florida.

823.41.text:
I'll show you how I invested
in hotels down there."

825.80.text:
Sure enough, my friend learned
from this mentor

828.03.text:
and became one of the wealthiest
real estate investors in the world.

831.25.text:
He persevered, because, you see,
everybody wants the good life,

834.78.text:
but not everybody's willing 
to persevere to get it.

842.05.text: Books you should see as hidden treasure.

846.50.text:
because as I said, 
mentors are great in person,

849.00.text:
but some of the great mentors
are no longer alive -

855.07.text:
But if I told you all those people
were in my house

858.16.text:
and they're going to be there
this Saturday answering questions,

861.19.text:
- magically I can make that happen -
would you show up at my house?

864.36.text:
Of course everybody would buy 
a plane ticket and end up in California.

867.78.text: They are there in my house.

869.36.text:
They're on my library.
They can be in your library, too.

873.60.text:
This is a man who made 
$160 billion for himself,

877.11.text:
more than all the other billionaires,
basically, combined.

879.92.text: He wrote a book on his death bed.

881.61.text: How many people have read it?

883.51.text:
It's a tragedy that not every 
businessperson's read a $5 book

886.49.text: by a man who built an empire.

889.72.text:
It's because the modern education system
has turned people off from books.

894.74.text:
You have to rewire your brain.
Let me show you a few quick tricks.

897.95.text:
First thing: stop seeing a book
like a one-time event.

900.73.text: See a book like a friend.

902.73.text:
You read it over and over.
You come back.

904.95.text:
And just like friends,
you pick a handful of them.

909.00.text:
There's 130 million.
You can't read that many.

911.37.text:
But 150 you can read over and over
for the rest of your life.

914.49.text:
There's no rule, either,
at how fast you have to read them,

917.85.text: at what pace. I set my own pace.

919.56.text:
People say, "How do you read
a book a day?"

923.18.text:
But sometimes, books only have 
one or two things worth reading.

926.22.text: In fact, most books only have that.

928.20.text: So I'll flip through the pages.

929.86.text: I like to go through it three times.

931.78.text:
First time, I read
the table of contents at the back.

934.27.text: The second time, I go a little faster.

936.08.text:
The third time, I just focus
on one chapter.

938.17.text:
See yourself like a gold miner
just looking for that one nugget.

941.18.text: Then put it back on the shelf.

943.22.text: The average American buys 17 books a year.

945.79.text:
Maybe reads one a month.
You should read at least one book a week,

949.61.text:
because remember, 
everybody wants the good life,

953.29.text:
but not everybody's 
willing to read to get it.

961.84.text:
One of the first books that I read, this
11-set volume I got from my grandfather,

967.79.text: there was a quote that I wrote down.

970.07.text:
"A nation is born stoic
and dies epicurean."

974.16.text:
Stoics were people 
willing to sacrifice present pleasure

980.50.text: You could say they were investors.

988.07.text: There's a saying, "If you're in a room

989.73.text:
and you don't know who the sucker is,
you're the sucker."

992.85.text: You never want to be the sucker.

994.66.text: Guess what the media wants to do.

996.63.text: I can tell you, I'm from Hollywood.

998.38.text:
They bombard you.
We see on average 2,000 ads a day.

1001.50.text: They're trying to sell you something.

1004.97.text:
Luxury comes at the cost 
of killing your hopes,

1011.10.text: So toughen up a little bit.

1014.70.text:
When was the last time you
went a week without eating sugar?

1018.20.text:
Or walked instead of taken a car
to get groceries?

1023.53.text: Or turned the air conditioning off?

1025.34.text:
Toughen yourself up.
Take a cold shower.

1028.76.text:
Everybody wants, but not everybody
toughens up to get the good life.

1040.34.text:
I'll share with you my favorite poem,
Chief Tecumseh.

1049.52.text: Beautify all things in your life.

1051.96.text: Seek to make your life long,

1053.67.text:
and its purpose 
in the service of your people."

1056.62.text: Mentors will help you do that.

1058.44.text: They are the shortcut that you want.

1060.38.text: You don't want to do it the hard way.

1062.53.text:
Find a mentor, no matter 
if you're just starting out

1067.44.text: There's always someone to learn from.

1072.61.text:
Be humble. Persevere.
Read more. Toughen up.

1078.59.text:
Remember, it's going to be
a little bit hard.

1080.75.text:
It's like Tom Hanks says 
in that one movie,

1086.09.text: The hard is what makes it great."

1089.75.text:
If you do these things,
you will find the good life.
